_header: Be the father what may be / Well is the child that may thee
_description: A proverbial saying translating the Latin, ‘Qualicunque pater vigeat puer est bene prosper’ — one couplet

BodDou52.Transcription: Be the fadur what he bewelle is the chylde to the
BodDou52.Editions:
Pantin,  William A. 
             “A Medieval Collection of Latin and English Proverbs…from Rylands
                Latin MS. 394.” 
             Bulletin of the John Rylands Library
         14 (1930): 81-114: 106, 105.
Förster,  Max. 
             “Die Mittelenglische Sprichwörtersammlung in Douce 52.” 
             Festschrift zum XII Deutschen Neuphilolgentage in München
                1906.
            E. Stollreither, ed. 
         Erlangen (1906): 40-64: 55.

BLHar665.Transcription: Who þat euer þe fadir beWell ys þe child þat may þe
BLHar665.Note: Above it the Latin proverbial saying, “De patre non cura dum felix sit genitura” (f. 195v) and to left in margin, “versus bonus.”

RylandsLat394.Transcription:
Be the fader what may bewell is þe childe þat may
                    thee
RylandsLat394.Note:
Written all on one line; translating ‘Qualicunque pater vigeat
                        puer est bene prosper’, which follows it in this MS.
RylandsLat394.Editions:
Pantin,  William A. 
             “A Medieval Collection of Latin and English Proverbs…from Rylands
                Latin MS. 394.” 
             Bulletin of the John Rylands Library
         14 (1930): 81-114: 106, 105.
